resource.chars:
[paragraph].70. <u>Hydra</u> * the ova are developed in similar processes of the
lower part of the body - But among the <u>Hydroid Polyphs</u> the ovarium of Coryne, Syncoryne, and Corymorpha, as described
by Sars Lowen & Steenstrup are most interesting - they 
commence as tubercules of the stem afterwards become bodies
precisely resembling the ovaria of the <u>Diphydæ</u> and finally (fig. 42)
deaching themselves develope regular tentacles from their margin
the ova are formed between the two membranes of the inner sac †
[paragraph].71. What has now been advanced will perhaps be deemed evidence
sufficient to demonstate 1<sup>sly</sup> that the organ of these various families are traceable back to same point in the way
of development or 2<sup>ndly</sup> when this [text?] cannot be done, that
they are connected by natural gradations with organs which 
are so traceable in which case accordingly to the principles 
advanced in ([paragraph] 57) the various organs are homologous and
the families have a real affinity to one another and 
should form one group.
[paragraph] 72. Perhaps the view that I have taken will be more clear
if I throw it into a tabular form placing opposite one another
those organs in the different families for the homologies of which
there is, I think, sufficient evidence, thus:

†Note. "The axis of the bell is occuplied by a membranous sac - which 
is a prolongation of the nutritive canal and answers to the
alimentary canity of the alimentary polypes - the ova are
developed in regular series in the interval between this alimentary
capusule and the parietes of the outer sac, in an intermediate
membranous sac distinguished by its yellowish brown colour"

See also Devernoy ann. d.s. <u>Cuvier. leçons d'anat: Comparée</u>. T.viii
nat: for Nov<sup>r</sup> 1845                  <u>Organs de Generation du Zoophytes</u> p. 860
8
